questions.text: The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the:
questions.solution:
The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome. 

The Y chromosome has a sex determining region called the SRY gene (Sex-determining Region of the Y chromosome). If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called Testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH), a peptide hormone, that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

In absence of the Y chromosome and the SRY gene consequently, the gonads will develop as ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the fallopian tubes and the upper part of the vagina.

Thus, the fate of the Mullerian duct, whether is regresses or differentiates is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromsome, respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct dosage for DMPA injectable?
questions.solution:
DMPA is depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate.

The dosage for injectable DMPA is 150 mg every 3 months.

It acts by bringing changes in the cervical mucus, making the endometrium hostile and preventing ovulation.

Disadvantage – spotting and intermediate bleeding.

 Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were recently launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas.

questions.text: A child is brought with features of meningitis. Tubercular meningitis is suspected. Which of the following finding in the cerebrospinal fluid will be seen in tubercular meningitis?
questions.solution:
Lymphocytes are seen in tubercular meningitis.

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Chloride Low Very low Normal
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes

Tubercular meningitis

  • Common between 6 months and 4 years of age
  • Usually spread by hematogenous route
  • Gelatinous exudate deposition in the corticomeningeal blood vessels leads to hydrocephalus.
  • Three stages
    • Prodromal stage
    • Stage of meningitis
    • Stage of coma
  • CSF study shows reduced sugar level, increased protein level, and lymphocytosis.
  • Treatment includes antitubercular drugs for 12 months and corticosteroids (to reduce neurologic sequelae).

questions.text: A 3 week old neonate presents to the OPD for the first time. He was born by vaginal delivery at home and has not received any vaccines. Which of the following vaccines would be indicated at this visit, as per the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible upto the age of 1 year.

Other Options:

Option B: Hepatitis B should be given within 24 hours of birth.

Option C: OPV-0 should be given at birth or as early as possible within the first 15 days.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for female with atrophic vaginitis with complains of itching?
questions.solution:
Atrophic vaginitis is treated with topical estrogen vaginal cream.

Use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally each day for 1 to 2 weeks generally provides relief. Systemic estrogen therapy should be considered to prevent recurrence of this disorder.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of the nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. Histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

It can be diagnosed as rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodule, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma 

Adding to this, the given histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass

questions.text: Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes do not include
questions.solution:
The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring.

The masses are:

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil or the adenoids
  • Palatine tonsils or simply the tonsils
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils (in fossa of Rosenmüller)
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules (in the posterior pharyngeal wall)

questions.text: Which of the following auscultatory findings do you expect to hear in a child during clinical examination in a child with an ASD?
questions.solution:
In Atrial septal defect (ASD), the characteristic finding is that the second heart sound is widely split and fixed during all phases of respiration.

Other options:

  • In Ventricular septal defect (VSD) – Wide variable splitting of the 2nd heart sound which is masked by the pansystolic murmur.
  • In Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) – the first sound is accentuated and the second sound is narrowly or paradoxically split.
  • In the Coarctation of the aorta – the first sound is accentuated, the second sound is normally split with a loud aortic component.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought to the ER after ingestion of a foreign body 30 minutes ago. X-ray findings are given below. The appropriate step in management is _____.

choices.text: Observation and follow up in 24 hours
Observation until the foreign body passes out in faeces

questions.solution:
The presence of a halo sign or double ring sign is indicative of the foreign body being a button battery.

Button batteries and sharp objects in the esophagus and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal.

Button batteries, in particular, are very dangerous foreign bodies, which must be expediently removed because they can cause:

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the esophagus in 4 hours

Injury is thought to be secondary to electrochemical burns from electrical discharge. Chemical burns from electrolyte alkali leakage and pressure necrosis may also contribute to mucosal injury.

Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the esophagus can be observed for up to 24 hr in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

This recent AIIMS question was based on a study conducted in 2018 demonstrated that early and frequent ingestion of honey in the crucial period between ingestion of the button battery and endoscopic removal can reduce the injury caused and improve patient outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves produces the extraocular movement as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows an elevation of the eye in adduction. It caused by the inferior oblique muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

Innervation of extraocular muscles:

  • Trochlear nerve (IV CN) innervates the superior oblique muscle.
  • Abducens nerve (VI CN) innervates the lateral rectus muscle.
  • The oculomotor nerve (III CN) innervates all the remaining muscles, which include: Superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles; and inferior oblique muscle.

 

Related Pearl: Extraocular muscles and their actions

Muscle Primary action Secondary action Tertiary action
Superior rectus Elevation Intorsion Adduction
Inferior rectus Depression Extorsion Adduction
Medial rectus Adduction --- --- 
Lateral rectus Abduction ---- ---
Superior oblique Intorsion Depression Abduction
Inferior oblique Extorsion Elevation Abduction

questions.text: A hypertensive patient died from respiratory distress following pneumonia caused by COVID-19(test positive). What should be recorded in line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
COVID-19 will be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate, as one of the antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place.

In this patient:

  • I(a)- Disease directly leading to death: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome(ARDS).
  • I(b)- Antecedent cause: Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Condition which gave rise to antecedent cause: COVID-19

Line II is filled with contributory factors/causes such as diabetes or hypertension.

Other scenarios:

1. In case of pregnancy, puerperium, or birth leading to death in conjunction with COVID-19, record the sequence of events as usual.

For example: 

  • I(a)- ARDS
  • I(b)- Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Pregnancy complicated by COVID-19

2. If an HIV patient is dead due to ARDS caused by COVID-19

  • I(a)- ARDS
  • I(b)- COVID-19
  • II- HIV disease

3. Note that COVID-19 patients may die of other diseases or accidents, such cases are not deaths due to COVID-19 and should not be certified as such. In case you think COVID-19 aggravated the consequences of the accident/disease, it may be reported in part II.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
questions.solution:
Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.

Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the posteroinferior or anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducent nerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs are proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

Other options :

Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in children young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint 

Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Iris epithelium is not derived from surface ectoderm. It is derived from neural ectoderm.

Lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium are all derivatives of surface ectoderm.

Related Pearl: Embryological derivatives of the eye

Neural Ectoderm

Surface Ectoderm

Mesoderm

Neural Crest

Smooth muscles of iris (sphincter and dilator pupillae)

Iris epithelium 

Crystalline lens

Extraocular muscles 

Corneal stroma, keratocytes, and endothelium

Ciliary epithelium

Corneal epithelium

Superotemporal part of Sclera

Sclera (except supero-temporally)

Ciliary muscles

Retina and retinal pigment epithelium

Conjunctival epithelium

Choroidal vessels

Iris stroma

Choroid stroma

Fibers of the optic nerve

Secondary and tertiary vitreous

Lacrimal and tarsal glands

Primary vitreous

Vascular     endothelium

Uveal and conjunctival melanocytes

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely
questions.solution:
Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are most likely condyloma acuminata, also called as venereal warts. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. Human papillomaviruses are implicated in causing this condition

Other options:

Option B- Molluscum contagiosum presents as a crop of small domed vesicles with central umbilication. It is caused by a poxvirus and it spreads by close sexual or nonsexual contact and by autoinoculation.

Option C- Chancroid appears as small papules that develop into painful pustules that ulcerate. They are associated with unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy.  It is caused by H. ducreyi.

Option D- Herpes appear as multiple crops of vesicles and ulcers.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is unemployed because he is unable to walk, as he lost his foot in an accident. The fact that he 'cannot walk' is explained by _______
questions.solution:
The fact that he cannot walk is explained by the disability, according to the concept given below.

Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap

  • Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function.
  • Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.
  • Handicap is experiencing disadvantages due to disability and inability to discharge obligations normally.

In the given example:

  • Accident: Disease (or disorder)
  • Loss of foot: Impairment (extrinsic or intrinsic)
  • Cannot walk: Disability (objectified)
  • Unemployed: Handicap (socialized)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. What is this history specific for  _______
questions.solution:
Whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding (specific for carcinoma of the cervix) →

Do per speculum examination.

a) If growth is visible → Punch biopsy

b) Nothing is visible → Do pap smear. If it is abnormal, then do a colposcopy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was found to have a height for age and gender to be 2 standard deviations below the median. Furthermore, his bone age was found to be equal to chronological age. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Familial short stature is most likely as bone age is equal to chronological age.

Bone age > chronological age in precocious puberty.

Bone age < chronological age in all other causes of short stature such as constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes.

Related Pearl: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: The image given below shows that the pregnancy is _______
questions.solution:
The sonographic image depicts a Twin peak/Lambda sign and it confirms a dichorionic pregnancy.

The placenta is seen extending between the amnion layers, forming a 'peak'.

In dichorionic gestation, the twins are separated by amniotic membranes and an intervening chorion. So, a thicker twin peak sign or lambda (λ) sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta.  If the division of the inner cell mass occurs within 3 days of fertilization, it results in this type of twin gestation. 

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation

The image given below shows the lambda/twin peak:

questions.text: If  the sensitivity and specificity  of a screening test are 90% and 95% respectively, calculate the positive likelihood ratio:
questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio of this screening test is 18.

A positive likelihood ratio, or LR+, is the probability that a positive test would be expected in a patient with a disease divided by the probability that a positive test would be expected in a patient without a disease. In other words, an LR+ is the true positivity rate divided by the false positivity rate.

Positive Likelihood Ratio= Sensitivity/(1-Specificity) 

LR+= 0.9/1-0.95= 0.9/0.05 = 18.

Similarly , Negative Likelihood Ratio= (1- Sensitivity)/Specificity

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hormone replacement therapy and breast cancer?

choices.text: The risk of cancer is not increased up to 3 years of HRT (combined)
The risk of cancer is not increased up to 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy
Breast cancer developing after HRT is usually low grade, with good prognosis
All the above statements are true

questions.solution:
All are true about hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and breast cancer.

  • The risk of breast cancer is not increased up to 3 years of HRT and 5 years of estrogen-only replacement therapy.
  • Lower risk is seen with the use of dydrogesterone in HRT.
  • HRT can cause recurrence of breast cancer and is, therefore, contraindicated in a woman who has been treated for breast cancer. Tibolone is safe.
  • HRT increases the density of breast tissue and subsequently impedes the screening programme of mammography.
  • Breast cancer developing subsequent to HRT is of low grade and with good prognosis.

questions.text: Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
questions.solution:
Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs.

Blackflies transmit onchocerciasis

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: An underweight adolescent girl is found to have the following finding on her ocular examination. What is the WHO grade for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency. According to the WHO grading of xerophthalmia, Bitot spots are classified as 1B.

Bitos spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: All of the following are components of the Apgar score except _______
questions.solution:
Respiratory rate is not a component of Apgar score; however, respiratory effort is.

The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 parameters stated below.

  • It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth.
  • Components of APGAR score
    • Color (A, appearance)
    • Heart rate (P, pulse)
    • Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace)
    • Muscle tone (A, activity)
    • Respiratory effort (R) (Not respiratory rate)
  • The first minute of life also called the ‘Golden minute’ is the most crucial period to initiate resuscitation. Hence we should not wait for the APGAR score to initiate resuscitation.
  • The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS)?

choices.text: No separate centres for stroke, DM and cancer
Implementation in over 10 districts in 5 states
Subcentre has facility for diagnosis and treatment

questions.solution:
The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) has specialized facilities in district hospitals.

The NPCDCS has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, stroke.

It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states.

At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral is done.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain in abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/ul.  The most likely diagnosis is____________
questions.solution:
In this case, there is severe acute pain abdomen without fever and leucocytosis in a 28-week pregnant woman with fibroid. Hence the most likely diagnosis is torsion of fibroid.

Torsion of sub-serous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen but fever and leukocytosis are absent.

Red degeneration of fibroid presents with acute pain abdomen, vomiting. Leukocytosis and raised ESR will be evident.

questions.text: In Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome (MRKH), which of the following is absent?
questions.solution:
In Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome (MRKH), testes is absent. 

It has a Karyotype of 46,XX. So, the gonads present are ovaries (in contrast to Androgen Insensitivity syndrome where the testes are present).

Vagina: upper 2/3rd are absent but lower one-third is present as it develops from the urogenital sinus.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with a history of vaginal discharge without itching. On examination, the discharge was milky, foul-smelling, nonviscous, and adherent to the vaginal wall. She is not active sexually. On further testing, it was found that the discharge has very few lactobacilli and there was a presence of clue cells. What is the causative organism for the above condition _______
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is Bacterial Vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is termed vaginosis rather than vaginitis because it is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora rather than due to any specific infection.

It is not sexually transmitted and has a variable incubation period. About 50% of women are asymptomatic carriers of infection.

The presence of clue cells is one of the 4 criteria described in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

On microscopy, there is no abundance of polymorphs in a case of bacterial vaginosis as it is just an alteration of flora and not an inflammation.

  • The diagnosis is based on wet smear and culture.
  • The smear reveals clean background with few inflammatory cells and other organ­isms, but scanty lactobacilli. Many epithelial cells present a granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, the so-called clue cells. Gram stain is 90% sensitive.

questions.text: Which of the following gland is infected in hordeolum externum?
questions.solution:
Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of hair follicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland.

Hordeolum internum is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct.

The Chalazion is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.

The gland of Wolfring and gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
A thirsty child signifies some dehydration, not severe dehydration. 

In severe dehydration the child is:

  • Drowsy, lethargic or unconscious
  • Drinks poorly or not able to drink
  • Sunken eyes
  • Skin pinch goes back very slowly

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: Absolute contraindications of OCPs are all except ______
questions.solution:
OCP's have no adverse effects on the thyroid.

Contraindications of OCP

  • Cardiac disease, hypertension, smoker over 35 years
  • Diabetes
  • History of thrombosis, myocardial infarct, sickle cell anaemia, severe migraine
  • Chronic liver diseases such as cholestatic jaundice of pregnancy, cirrhosis of liver, adenoma, porphyrias
  • Breast cancer, gall bladder disease
  • Gross obesity
  • Patient on enzyme-inducing drugs like rifampicin, and antiepileptic except sodium valproate
  • 4–6 weeks prior to planned surgery
  • Lactating woman
  • Monilial vaginitis

questions.text: A 55 year old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was  retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is of a Leiomyoma.

The uterine body / corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, white-greyish with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of fungal hypopyon?
questions.solution:
Fungal keratitis causes a non-sterile hypopyon.

Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation. Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause.

Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer

  • Non-sterile
  • Thick and Fixed
  • Contains fungal filaments

questions.text: A 26 year old woman, G2P1, is informed after her first trimester scan , that the fetus has open spina bifida. At 30 weeks of gestation, her USG scan would most likely report:
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical vignette, at 30 weeks of gestation, her USG scan would most likely report a single deepest vertical pocket of 9 cm in a fetus with open spina bifida.

Spina bifida is one of the causes of polyhydramnios which is diagnosed when the single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is greater than 8 cm. 

Open spina bifida causes increased transudation from the meninges , leading to increasing amounts of liquor amnii production i.e. polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios is diagnosed when :

  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is greater than 24cm
  • Single deepest vertical pocket  (DVP) is greater than 8 cm
  • Amniotic fluid volume is greater than 2L

Other options :

Option A : AFI=4 cm implies oligohydramnios (AFI< 5 cm or DVP< 2cm).

Option B: DVP=2 cm implies oligohydramnios.

Option C : AFI = 10 cm implies normal AFI (5-25 cm).

 

Related Pearl: Causes of oligo and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal

Post-dated pregnancy, Pre- Eclampsia, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)

Spontaneous rupture of membranes

Diabetes, cardiac & renal diseases, liver failure

Fetal

Fetal anomalies, Renal agenesis, urethral defects (posterior valve, obstructive uropathy)

 

Neural tube defects, open spina bifida, anencephaly, abdominal wall defects, cleft palate, neck masses, aneuploidy, hydrops fetalis, twin to twin transfusion syndrome, multiple pregnancies 

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion Nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: A 2nd degree perineal tear involves :

choices.text: Internal anal sphincter + External anal sphincter

questions.solution:
A 2nd-degree perineal tear involves the perineal muscles i.e, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal muscles.

Other options :

Any involvement of the rectal mucosa is categorised as a 4th-degree tear. (a,c)

Internal and external anal sphincter involvement is categorised as 3c, 3rd-degree perineal tear (d).

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A 40-year-old construction worker involves in work where he gets repeatedly exposed to noise of around 100 dB at the construction site. This could lead to ____
questions.solution:
Repeated exposure to the sound of 100 dB can lead to permanent hearing loss.

Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when the sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a lacerated wound over the hand due to an accidental injury from the soiled & rusted knife. You decide to give him equine antitoxin as human antitoxin immunoglobulin was not available at the hospital. What standard dose of equine antitoxin would you use in this case?
questions.solution:
The standard dose of Equine antitoxin(anti-tetanus serum/ATS) is 1500 IU.

The standard dose of Human antitoxin(human tetanus hyper-immunoglobulin/TIG) is 250 IU. If this not available, equine antitoxin can be used.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

All type of wounds need surgical toilet followed by:

Previous doses of tetanus toxoid Clean and minor wound
Tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine Human tetanus Immune globulin
Unknown or <3 doses Yes No
≥3 doses Only if the last dose is given ≥10 years ago No

 

Previous doses of tetanus toxoid All other wounds
Tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine Human tetanus Immune globulin
Unknown or <3 doses Yes Yes
≥3 doses Only if the last dose is given ≥5 years ago No

questions.text: The following image represents
questions.solution:
Option a: Rashtriya swasthya bima yojana

Option c: Integrated child development services

Option d: Mission indradhanush

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with precocious puberty, bony lesions, and hyperpigmented skin lesions, as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty, bony lesions (polyostotic fibrous dysplasia), and cafe au lait spots, as shown in the picture, are features of McCune–Albright syndrome.

McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Females > Males

questions.text: Catch up, Keep up and Follow up strategy is done for elimination of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Catch up, Keep up and Follow up is a special strategy for global elimination of Measles.

Special Immunization activity is held for Measles Elimination in the form of Catch-up, Keep up and Follow up phases

Catch-up:

All the children between 9 months to 10 years will receive a supplementary dose of Measles regardless of previous Measles vaccination or Measles illness

Target: more than 90% of eligible children

Keep-up:

To increase measles vaccination in routine immunization to more than 90% of successive birth cohorts

Follow-up:

A periodic event that will be conducted every 3-5 years after catch-up phase, wherein all the children born after catch up phase and more than 9 months of age will be given an additional dose of Measles vaccine regardless of previous Measles vaccination or Measles illness

Target: more than 90% of eligible children

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl complains of low-grade fever and mild discomfort in her throat. On examination, a membrane is seen over the tonsil and can be removed easily. After removal of the membrane, an irregular ulcer is seen on the surface of the tonsil. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Vincent's angina. It is caused by the fusiform bacillus and Borrreli vincentii.

Vincent’s angina:

  • Present with low grade fever and sore throat & membrane over tonsil.
  • Membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcer over tonsil.
  • Throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes namely Borrreli vincentii.

questions.text: A two-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting; the X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis of duodenal atresia is suggested by the presence of a “double-bubble” sign on a plain abdominal radiograph, which is caused by the distension of a filled stomach and proximal duodenum.
  • Duodenal atresia results from failed recanalization of the intestinal lumen during gestation. A history of polyhydramnios is present; half of the infants seen with duodenal atresia are premature. The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distention, which is usually noted on the 1st day of life. 

Management: The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression and intravenous fluid replacement. The typical surgical repair for duodenal atresia is duodenoduodenostomy.

questions.text: The main objective of the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan-aushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) is to ___________

choices.text: Make quality, generic medicines affordable to all
Enhance quality of life and increase employment for the differently abled
Mobilise the Indian youth against issues like women empowerment and trafficking

questions.solution:
The Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Jan-aushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) carries the objective of making quality, generic medicines affordable for everyone especially the lower socio-economic groups. BPPI (Bureau of Pharma PSUs of India), under the administrative control of the Department of Pharmaceuticals, Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers, Government of India is the implementation agency for the PMBJP.

The mission of this programme includes creating awareness and demand for generic medicines through education and supply of such medications.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): The Arnold's nerve innervates the skin over a small part of the ear and external auditory canal. In patients with chronic cough, scratching or mechanical stimulation of ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough.

questions.text: A new nurse asks your advice regarding the disposal of an unsterile vacutainer. In response, you would answer her to dispose of it in ____.
questions.solution:
The contaminated vacutainer to be discarded in the red bag or container. As the vacutainer comes under recyclable contaminated waste.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

The changes as per the new Biomedical waste management (amendment) rules, 2018 have been included in the above table and highlighted in green.

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

In absence of above facilities, shredding
or mutilation or combination of
sterilization and shredding.

human and animal cell

research, industrial

of biological, residual

due to use of chemicals

laboratories and floor

house-keeping and

etc.

mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable Contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes(without needles and fixed needle syringes), vaccutainers with needles cut and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by -  Shredding/mutilation

And later -  Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/Road making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/Mutilation/
Encapsulation

Glassware

Metallic Body implants

Microwaving/Hydroclaving

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: Lathyrism is caused by which of the following toxic compounds?
questions.solution:
BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs.

The water soluble property of the toxin is used in removing from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

Disease   Food Substance/Contaminant  Toxic Principle 
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA 
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup.  On examination size of the uterus corresponds to 26 weeks of gestation and the fetal heart rate is 130 beats/min.  Amniotic fluid index is 4 in the sonogram.  Which of the following fetal anomalies is not likely to be associated  ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of Oligohydramnios and it is not likely to be associated with Oesophageal atresia

Maternal causes Fetal causes Placental causes
Post-dated pregnancy Fetal anomalies  Placental insufficiency
Pre-eclampsia  Renal agenesis, urethral defects (posterior valve, obstructive uropathy) Failure of secretion: Amnion Nodosum
NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors     

Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)

Spontaneous rupture of membranes

questions.text: You are charting the partograph of a 24-year-old woman in the labor ward. The graph crosses to the right of the action line. Which zone of the partograph will you find yourself in?
questions.solution:
Once the graph crosses to the right of the action line, you enter the red zone.

WHO Simplified Partograph-this simplified partograph is color-coded :

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is colored green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is colored red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labor.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is colored amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.
